title: Robin Quillivic
text:
I am a post-doctoral researcher at the Centre Européen de Sociologie et de Science Politique (CESSP) and resident at the Centre for Complex Systems (ISC-PIF), where I develop Clinical Decision Support Systems (CDSS) for PTSD detection through Natural Language Processing.
I hold a Ph.D. in Computer Science from École Pratique des Hautes Études (EPHE) and currently lead the 150k€ CNRS-funded TALANT project on trauma language analysis.

title: Robin Quillivic
text:
Research Interests
My research focuses on applying computational methods to understand and detect mental health conditions through language analysis:

Natural Language Processing for Mental Health: Developing NLP techniques to identify linguistic markers of psychological conditions
Clinical Decision Support Systems (CDSS): Creating AI-powered tools to assist healthcare professionals in diagnosis and treatment
Trauma and PTSD Detection: Analyzing language patterns to identify and understand post-traumatic stress disorder
Psycholinguistics: Investigating the relationship between language and psychological states
Explainable AI: Ensuring transparency and interpretability in AI systems for healthcare applications

title: Research Projects
text:
Traitement Automatique du LANgage Traumatique

Funding: 150k€ CNRS Innovation Prematuration Grant
Role: Principal Investigator
Collaborator: Prof. Frédérique Gayraud
Institution: CESSP/ISC-PIF, Paris

The TALANT project aims to develop automated tools for trauma language analysis by combining computational linguistics, psychology, and clinical research. This interdisciplinary project focuses on creating Clinical Decision Support Systems (CDSS) for PTSD detection through Natural Language Processing.
Key Objectives: - Develop NLP algorithms for trauma language identification - Create clinical decision support tools for healthcare professionals - Validate linguistic markers of PTSD across different populations - Establish ethical frameworks for AI in mental health applications
